newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Prodi meets dairy farmers on quota dispute.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Prodi meets dairy farmers on quota dispute.

text.p: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi met dairy farmers on Monday to try to resolve a dispute over tough EU fines for milk overproduction that has sparked nearly two weeks of protests by farmers who say they are being ruined.

Farmers dismantled blockades in Italy's financial capital Milan ahead of the talks with Prodi. Milan's main Linate airport had to be shut briefly last week because farmers in tractors had barricaded the access routes.
Protests were staged near the northwestern city of Turin, at Verona and Venice airports and on a main southern motorway after farmers vowed to fight on until their demands were accepted.
Prodi, who met the farmers last week for a first round of talks, responded by ordering "all appropriate means" to be used to ensure that people and transport could move freely.
The dispute centres on European Union "super-levy" fines, due to be paid by Friday, for overshooting Italy's national 1995-96 milk quota of 9.9 million tonnes by some 400,000 tonnes.
The fines add up to some 370 billion lire ($230 million).
Farmers want the government to pay the fines but Prodi has refused, offering cheap loans instead.

Fausto Bertinotti, whose hard-left Communist Refoundation party is a key government ally, said the crisis is the fault of previous governments who established "ridiculous" quotas. Italy's milk consumption is 18 million tonnes.

Agriculture Minister Michele Pinto has formally asked the European Commission to raise Italy's quota to 10.5 million tonnes and has outlined a package of aid measures, but the government says it cannot overlook the tens of thousands of farmers who have stuck to their quotas or have already paid up.

According to the government, some 15,000 farmers have been hit by fines but the farmers put the figure at 40,000 and say the government is to blame for erroneously calculating the quotas which forced them to overproduce inadvertently. ($1=1,595 lire)
